articles.headline: Bank Case on Bonuses Shifts Focus to Lawyers
articles.snippet: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.
articles.abstract: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The finger-pointing in Merrill Lynch’s bonus troubles shifted to a new target on Monday in two court documents that essentially said: blame the lawyers.

articles.headline: Wikipedia to Limit Changes to Articles on People
articles.snippet: Founded on the concept that anyone could change its content, the online encyclopedia is requiring reviews on articles about living people after embarrassing incidents.
articles.abstract: Founded on the concept that anyone could change its content, the online encyclopedia is requiring reviews on articles about living people after embarrassing incidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Wikipedia, one of the 10 most popular sites on the Web, was founded about eight years ago as a long-shot experiment to create a free encyclopedia from the contributions of volunteers, all with the power to edit, and presumably improve, the content.

articles.headline: C.I.A. Abuse Cases Detailed in Report on Detainees
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. named a federal prosecutor to examine abuse of prisoners held by the C.I.A., as officials released a 2004 report detailing abuses inside C.I.A.-run prisons overseas.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. named a federal prosecutor to examine abuse of prisoners held by the C.I.A., as officials released a 2004 report detailing abuses inside C.I.A.-run prisons overseas.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. named a veteran federal prosecutor on Monday to examine abuse of prisoners held by the Central Intelligence Agency, after the Justice Department released a long-secret report showing interrogators choked a prisoner repeatedly and threatened to kill another detainee’s children.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Breathing Easier, G.M. Not in Rush in Opel Deal
articles.snippet: Now that the intense financial pressure on General Motors has eased, the automaker has the luxury of time to consider new alternatives for selling its Opel unit.
articles.abstract: Now that the intense financial pressure on General Motors has eased, the automaker has the luxury of time to consider new alternatives for selling its Opel unit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  Now that the intense financial pressure on General Motors has eased, the automaker has the luxury of time to consider new alternatives for selling its Opel unit.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: China Racing Ahead of U.S. in the Drive to Go Solar
articles.snippet: With cheap loans, labor and electricity, Chinese companies are pulling ahead in the solar product industry.
articles.abstract: With cheap loans, labor and electricity, Chinese companies are pulling ahead in the solar product industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WUXI, China  President Obama wants to make the United States “the world’s leading exporter of renewable energy,” but in his seven months in office, it is China that has stepped on the gas in an effort to become the dominant player in green energy  especially in solar power, and even in the United States.

articles.headline: A Few Dollars at a Time, Patrons Support Artists on the Web
articles.snippet: Kickstarter, an Internet start-up, chooses artistic projects it deems worthy of support, then invites mini-patrons to contribute money.
articles.abstract: Kickstarter, an Internet start-up, chooses artistic projects it deems worthy of support, then invites mini-patrons to contribute money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Earl Scioneaux III is not a famous music producer like Quincy Jones. He is a simple audio engineer in New Orleans who mixes live albums of local jazz musicians by day and creates electronic music by night. He had long wanted to pursue his dream of making his own album that married jazz and electronica, but he had no easy way to raise the $4,000 he needed for production.

articles.headline: Obama to Nominate Bernanke to 2nd Term at Fed
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke, a Republican appointed by President Bush, has been commended for his handling of the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke, a Republican appointed by President Bush, has been commended for his handling of the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Tuesday will nominate Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, administration officials said.

articles.headline: Bernanke’s Next Tasks Will Be Undoing His First
articles.snippet: Ben S. Bernanke’s challenge in his second term will be to undo much of what made him a hero during his first.
articles.abstract: Ben S. Bernanke’s challenge in his second term will be to undo much of what made him a hero during his first.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As he looks forward to a second term as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Ben S. Bernanke’s biggest challenge will be to undo much of what made him a hero during his first term.

articles.headline: Index Shows an Improvement in Home Prices
articles.snippet: Standard & Poor’s Case-Shiller index showed that home prices in 18 of the 20 major cities it studied increased in June.
articles.abstract: Standard & Poor’s Case-Shiller index showed that home prices in 18 of the 20 major cities it studied increased in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a convincing sign that the worst housing slump of modern times is coming to an end, prices are starting to rise in nearly all of the nation’s large cities.
